Macabéa survives on hot dogs and Coca-Cola, representing cultural colonization
The narrator constantly interrupts the story to discuss his own writing process
Written by Brazil's most celebrated female writer, known for existential prose
Macabéa has a boyfriend, Olímpico, who is equally poor but more ambitious
The protagonist listens obsessively to Rádio Relógio, finding comfort in facts and time announcements
Features a fortune teller, Madame Carlota, who predicts a glamorous future for Macabéa
The novel explores themes of poverty, alienation, and the invisible lives of the marginalized
Macabéa is unaware of her own suffering, living in a state of innocent ignorance
The narrative style is fragmented, mixing stream of consciousness with social commentary
Olímpico abandons Macabéa for her coworker Glória, who is more worldly
The protagonist has limited vocabulary and rarely speaks
The novel's title refers to Macabéa's moment of importance, which comes at her death
The story is preceded by thirteen alternative titles, emphasizing narrative uncertainty
Macabéa dies after being hit by a yellow Mercedes-Benz
The narrator grapples with the ethics of telling a poor woman's story
Dedicated "to the author in truth, which am I," emphasizing questions of authorship
A meditation on social inequality, representation, and the purpose of literature

profiles.name: O Cortiço
clues: Set in a Rio de Janeiro tenement during the late 19th century
Features João Romão, an exploitative Portuguese immigrant who builds his fortune
The tenement itself functions as a collective protagonist representing Brazilian society
Published in 1890, it's considered the masterpiece of Brazilian Naturalism
The novel depicts the lives of dozens of characters living in cramped, unsanitary conditions
João Romão has a relationship with Bertoleza, an enslaved woman he deceives
The Portuguese merchant competes with his wealthy neighbor Miranda
Features Rita Baiana, whose sensuality and music embody Afro-Brazilian culture
The novel explores how environment and heredity shape human behavior
Jerônimo, a Portuguese worker, transforms after falling under Rita Baiana's influence
The tenement expands as João Romão exploits his tenants and workers
The narrative employs deterministic philosophy characteristic of Naturalist fiction
João Romão eventually betrays Bertoleza when he wants to marry Miranda's daughter
The novel depicts racial mixing and cultural syncretism in Brazilian society
Features detailed descriptions of daily life, celebrations, and conflicts
The wash-women's quarrels and the fire in the tenement are dramatic centerpieces
Pombinha's character arc represents innocence corrupted by environment
The novel critiques capitalism, exploitation, and social climbing
João Romão transforms from merchant to respectable businessman through ruthless means
A foundational text examining class, race, and social mobility in late 19th century Brazil

profiles.name: Iracema
clues: Subtitled "Legend of Ceará," this romantic novel blends fiction with indigenous mythology
The title character is a beautiful indigenous woman whose name is an anagram of "America"
She is the virgin guardian of the secret of jurema, a sacred indigenous drink
The novel tells the story of the encounter between indigenous peoples and Portuguese colonizers
Published in 1865 during Brazil's Romantic period
The protagonist falls in love with Martim, a Portuguese warrior
The story is set in colonial Ceará, in Northeast Brazil
Written in poetic prose filled with lush descriptions of Brazilian nature
The heroine has "lips of honey" and "hair darker than the wing of a sacred bird"
The author was a prominent figure in Brazil's Indianist literary movement
The protagonist betrays her people's sacred trust by sharing the sacred drink with her lover
The couple's son, Moacir, represents the first Brazilian, born of indigenous and European heritage
The heroine dies of sadness and despair after being abandoned
The novel explores themes of love, sacrifice, and the origins of Brazilian identity
The protagonist's brother and the chief represent important tribal connections
Another chief from a rival tribe also desires the heroine
The narrative romanticizes indigenous culture while depicting colonization
Uses indigenous words and poetic language to create a distinctly Brazilian style
The novel was controversial for its depiction of miscegenation
Remains a foundational text of Brazilian Romanticism and national identity

profiles.name: Memórias Póstumas de Brás Cubas
clues: Narrated by a dead man who tells his life story from beyond the grave
The novel begins with the narrator's death and funeral, then moves backwards and forwards in time
Published in 1881, it marked a radical break from Romanticism to Brazilian Realism
The narrator addresses readers as "worms" and constantly makes ironic commentary
Brás Cubas was a wealthy, privileged man who achieved nothing significant in life
Features short, fragmented chapters with philosophical digressions
The narrator describes his love affair with Virgília, a married woman
Brás Cubas invents a "anti-hypochondria plaster" that fails commercially
The novel's subtitle is "The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas"
Written by the founder and first president of the Brazilian Academy of Letters
The narrator declares he had "no children" and therefore "transmitted no misery to anyone"
Features the character Quincas Borba, a philosopher who creates "Humanitism"
The narrative style influenced modernist writers with its experimental structure
Brás Cubas's privileged perspective reveals the hypocrisy of Brazilian elite society
The novel includes a dedication "To the Worm that First Gnawed My Cold Flesh"
Features satirical commentary on 19th century Brazilian society and its pretensions
The narrator's self-awareness and cynicism create a darkly comic tone
Explores themes of futility, vanity, and the meaninglessness of elite existence
Revolutionized Brazilian literature with its metafictional techniques
Considered one of the first truly modern novels in world literature

profiles.name: Gabriela, Cravo e Canela
clues: Set in the fictional coastal town of Ilhéus during the 1920s cacao boom
The title character is a beautiful migrant from the sertão who becomes a cook
Gabriela's skin has the color of cinnamon (canela) and she smells like cloves (cravo)
The novel depicts the transformation of Ilhéus from a violent frontier town to modern society
Published in 1958 by an author closely associated with Bahian culture
Nacib, a Syrian-Brazilian bar owner, falls in love with Gabriela
The novel opens with the murder of Sinhazinha Mendonça and her lover by her husband
Features the conflict between traditional "colonels" and progressive reformers
Mundinho Falcão represents modernity and challenges the old order led by Ramiro Bastos
Nacib marries Gabriela but tries to change her free-spirited nature
The discovery of Gabriela's infidelity leads Nacib to annul their marriage
The novel explores changing attitudes toward honor killings and women's rights
Features colorful secondary characters representing Ilhéus's diverse population
The cacao economy drives the town's growth and social conflicts
Gabriela's sensuality and naturalness contrast with restrictive social conventions
The novel was adapted into a famous television series and film
Explores themes of progress, tradition, and personal freedom
Nacib and Gabriela reunite after he accepts her as she truly is
Combines social chronicle with romantic storytelling
Represents the author's most popular work internationally

profiles.name: O Quinze
clues: Published in 1930, it was the author's debut novel at age 20, making her the youngest member admitted to the Brazilian Academy of Letters
The title refers to the catastrophic drought year of 1915 in the Brazilian Northeast
Written by Rachel de Queiroz, the first woman elected to the Brazilian Academy of Letters
Features two parallel narratives: one following the suffering retirantes and another depicting educated landowners
The protagonist Conceição is a schoolteacher who struggles with her feelings for the cowboy Vicente
Vicente's family becomes part of the mass exodus of drought refugees fleeing to the coast
The novel depicts the harsh reality of the sertão during extended periods without rain
Conceição's grandmother Inácia represents the traditional matriarchal authority of rural families
The work is considered a foundational text of Brazilian Regionalism and social literature
Chronicles the journey of Vicente's family from their ranch to Fortaleza seeking survival
The novel contrasts the intellectual world of Conceição with the raw survival struggle of Vicente's family
Features graphic descriptions of starvation, death, and the desperation of drought victims
Cordulina's death scene is one of the most harrowing moments in Brazilian literature
The work influenced the social novel tradition in Brazilian literature
Vicente eventually takes his family to São Paulo seeking work in the coffee plantations
Conceição's inability to bridge the social gap with Vicente reflects class divisions
The drought serves as both literal disaster and metaphor for social inequality
The novel drew from the author's firsthand experience of the 1915 drought in Ceará
Published during the Brazilian Modernist period but maintains regionalist characteristics
A landmark work depicting the suffering of the poor in Northeast Brazil

profiles.name: A Paixão Segundo G.H.
clues: The novel's structure includes an introductory note explaining that G.H. are the initials on the protagonist's luggage
Written entirely as an internal monologue over the course of a single day
The protagonist is a wealthy sculptor living alone in a penthouse in Rio de Janeiro
The transformative event occurs when she enters her maid's recently vacated room
She encounters a cockroach emerging from a wardrobe in the stark, emptied room
The act of biting into the cockroach's white paste becomes a mystical communion
Published in 1964 by Brazil's most celebrated female writer
The novel explores existential themes through an experience of radical alterity
G.H. undergoes a dissolution of her identity and social persona
The work is considered one of the most challenging texts in Brazilian literature
Written in a hypnotic, repetitive style that mirrors the protagonist's psychological state
Each chapter begins with the last line of the previous chapter, creating circular continuity
The novel questions the boundaries between human and non-human, self and other
The protagonist's journey moves from civilization toward a primitive, pre-linguistic state
The maid's room contains only white walls with primitive drawings
G.H. experiences a form of ego death and mystical union with the material world
The novel explores themes of disgust, transcendence, and the nature of consciousness
The cockroach becomes a vehicle for exploring questions of existence and being
The work influenced philosophical and feminist readings of Brazilian literature
Combines existentialism, mysticism, and phenomenology in a unique narrative experiment

profiles.name: Triste Fim de Policarpo Quaresma
clues: The protagonist is an aging bureaucrat obsessed with Brazilian nationalism and indigenous culture
Quaresma petitions the government to make Tupi-Guarani the official language of Brazil
He studies Brazilian flora, fauna, folklore, and attempts to implement indigenous agricultural methods
Published in 1915 by Lima Barreto, a mulatto writer who faced racial discrimination
Quaresma retires to a rural property to prove the fertility of Brazilian soil
His idealistic agricultural project fails miserably due to pests, drought, and lack of knowledge
The novel satirizes romantic nationalism and naive patriotism in early 20th century Brazil
Quaresma's goddaughter Adelaide dreams of romantic love but faces disappointment
Major Ricardo Coração dos Outros plays guitar and serenades women throughout Rio de Janeiro
During the Armada Revolt, Quaresma volunteers to fight for the government
He becomes disillusioned when he witnesses the president's authoritarian brutality
Quaresma writes a letter to the president criticizing corruption and violence
He is arrested, imprisoned, and ultimately executed as a traitor
The novel's title translates to "The Sad End of Policarpo Quaresma"
Quaresma represents the tragic fate of the idealist in a corrupt society
The work is a pre-Modernist novel that critiques Brazilian society and politics
Features both comic and tragic elements in its portrait of misguided patriotism
Quaresma's library contains volumes on Brazilian history, ethnography, and linguistics
The novel reflects Lima Barreto's own disillusionment with the early Brazilian Republic
Considered one of the most important satirical novels in Brazilian literature

profiles.name: Quincas Borba
clues: The title character is a philosopher who appears in an earlier novel by the same author
The protagonist creates a unique philosophy, which becomes the central ideological conflict
Published in 1891 by Machado de Assis, continuing his exploration of Brazilian society
The protagonist inherits a fortune and a dog that share his former master's name
Rubião moves from provincial Barbacena to Rio de Janeiro high society
He falls under the influence of the opportunistic couple Cristiano Palha and Sofia
Rubião becomes obsessed with Sofia, misinterpreting her calculated friendliness as romantic interest
The novel depicts how Rubião is systematically exploited and manipulated by false friends
Cristiano Palha uses Rubião's money to establish himself in business and society
Major Siqueira and his wife Dona Tonica also exploit Rubião's generosity
Rubião gradually descends into madness, believing himself to be Napoleon III
The protagonist's inherited dog dies, symbolizing the death of the philosopher's ideas
Rubião ends up destitute and insane, dying alone in Barbacena
The novel satirizes the greed, hypocrisy, and social climbing of Rio's bourgeoisie
Sofia is portrayed as a beautiful but cold and calculating woman
The philosophy of Humanitism justifies selfishness and exploitation as natural law
The novel explores themes of illusion, exploitation, and the corruption of innocence
Rubião's Napoleon delusion represents his complete disconnection from reality
The work is darker and more pessimistic than Machado's earlier novels
Features Machado's characteristic ironic narrative voice and psychological insight

profiles.name: Menino de Engenho
clues: The novel is semi-autobiographical, drawing from the author's childhood experiences
Opens with a traumatic event: the protagonist's father murders his mother in a fit of madness
The orphaned boy Carlinhos is sent to live at his grandfather's sugar plantation in Northeast Brazil
Published in 1932 by José Lins do Rego, inaugurating the "Sugar Cane Cycle" novels
The narrative recreates the world of traditional sugar plantations in decline
Carlinhos's grandfather is a patriarchal figure who rules the engenho with absolute authority
The boy witnesses and participates in the sensual, violent world of plantation life
Features vivid descriptions of sugar cane cultivation, harvesting, and processing
Carlinhos learns about sex from slaves, workers, and his own explorations
The novel depicts racial hierarchies and the exploitation of workers on the plantation
Aunt Sinhazinha represents the stern, religious authority of plantation women
The boy develops a close relationship with old slaves who tell him stories
The novel portrays childhood as a time of both innocence and premature exposure to adult realities
Features the landscape and culture of the Paraíba river valley region
The work influenced the development of Brazilian Regionalism in the 1930s
Depicts the decline of the traditional sugar aristocracy in the face of modernization
The engenho represents a complete social world with its own hierarchies and customs
Carlinhos's education comes from experience rather than formal schooling
The novel's episodic structure follows the boy's experiences and discoveries
Considered the first novel in José Lins do Rego's important five-novel cycle

profiles.name: São Bernardo
clues: The narrator Paulo Honório is a self-made landowner who writes his own life story
The novel begins with Paulo Honório attempting to organize others to write his biography, then deciding to do it himself
Published in 1934 by Graciliano Ramos, exploring themes of possession and dehumanization
Paulo Honório rose from poverty through ruthless ambition, violence, and exploitation
The protagonist acquires a valuable plantation through manipulation and intimidation
The protagonist treats everything and everyone as property to be dominated
He marries Madalena, a young schoolteacher with humanistic ideals
Paulo Honório's possessiveness and brutality gradually destroy their relationship
Madalena represents sensitivity, education, and humanitarian values
The conflict between the couple reflects the clash between capitalism and humanism
Paulo Honório suspects Madalena of infidelity with various men on the plantation
His jealousy and cruelty drive Madalena to despair and eventual suicide
After Madalena's death, Paulo Honório reflects on his life with growing regret
The novel explores how capitalist relations deform human personality and relationships
Paulo Honório realizes too late that he has destroyed everything he valued
The narrative voice shifts between past and present, showing his evolving consciousness
The novel is written in spare, economical prose characteristic of Graciliano Ramos
Features psychological depth in its portrait of a man who has dehumanized himself
The protagonist's property becomes a symbol of oppressive social relations
Considered one of the masterpieces of Brazilian social-psychological fiction

profiles.name: Sentimento do Mundo
clues: Published in 1940 by Carlos Drummond de Andrade, one of Brazil's greatest poets
The collection marks a shift from the poet's earlier ironic style to social engagement
Written during World War II, reflecting global political turmoil
The title poem expresses the poet's expanded consciousness and social responsibility
Features the famous poem "Confidência do Itabirano" about the poet's hometown
Reflects the poet's political sympathies with leftist causes during this period
The poem "Mãos Dadas" (Hands Joined) declares solidarity with collective struggle
Contains "Elegia 1938," a meditation on poetry's role in dark times
The collection balances individual consciousness with social and political awareness
Drummond's style combines modernist experimentation with accessible language
The poems address themes of war, injustice, solidarity, and human suffering
"Noturno à Janela do Apartamento" depicts urban loneliness and alienation
The work shows influence of international events on Brazilian intellectual life
Drummond questions the poet's role in a world of violence and inequality
The collection represents Brazilian Modernist poetry at its mature phase
Features Drummond's characteristic blend of irony, melancholy, and social consciousness
"Os Mortos de Sobrecasaca" critiques bourgeois complacency
The poems reflect anxiety about the future of humanity
Drummond's voice remains individual even while embracing collective concerns
The collection influenced a generation of socially engaged Brazilian poets

profiles.name: Os Lusíadas
clues: Epic poem in ten cantos composed by Luís de Camões, published in 1572
Narrates Vasco da Gama's voyage to India, celebrating Portuguese maritime achievements
Written in ottava rima (eight-line stanzas) following classical epic conventions
The poem opens with the Portuguese fleet already in the Indian Ocean
Features interventions by Greek and Roman gods who help or hinder the voyage
Venus protects the Portuguese while Bacchus opposes them out of jealousy
The poem includes the famous episode of Inês de Castro, murdered for political reasons
Adamastor, the giant guardian of the Cape of Good Hope, is one of Camões's great creations
The work combines historical events with mythological elements
Camões himself participated in Portuguese colonial expeditions in Africa and Asia
The poem celebrates Portuguese discoveries while questioning their human cost
Features the Island of Love episode where Venus rewards the sailors
Vasco da Gama narrates Portuguese history to the King of Melinde
The poem elevated Portuguese language to the status of other European epic traditions
Considered the national epic of Portugal and Portuguese-speaking peoples
The opening line "As armas e os barões assinalados" echoes Virgil's Aeneid
The work reflects Renaissance humanist learning and classical education
Camões died in poverty despite creating Portugal's greatest literary work
The poem was written during Portugal's imperial golden age
Remains fundamental to Portuguese cultural identity and education

profiles.name: O Crime do Padre Amaro
clues: Published in 1875 by Eça de Queirós, pioneering Portuguese Realism
The protagonist is a young priest sent to the provincial town of Leiria
Amaro lodges at the house of São Joaneira and falls in love with her daughter Amélia
The novel depicts the corruption and hypocrisy of the Portuguese Catholic clergy
Amaro and Amélia begin a secret love affair despite his priestly vows
The work satirizes the conservative, backward society of provincial Portugal
Canon Dias represents the worldly, gluttonous, politically-connected clergy
Amélia becomes pregnant with Amaro's child
Amaro arranges for the baby to be taken to a "baby farmer" where it dies
The novel exposes child abandonment and infant mortality in 19th century Portugal
Amélia dies during a religious procession, holding a candle
Amaro faces no consequences for his actions, continuing his clerical career
The work was controversial for its criticism of the Catholic Church
Features detailed satire of provincial gossip, religious hypocrisy, and social mores
The novel shows influence of French Realist and Naturalist literature
Eça revised the novel multiple times, with significant differences between editions
The title character's name suggests both love (amaro = bitter/beloved) and moral ambiguity
The work contributed to Portuguese liberal anticlerical sentiment
Adapted multiple times for film, including by Mexican director Carlos Carrera
Considered one of the greatest Portuguese novels of the 19th century

profiles.name: Memorial do Convento
clues: Published in 1982 by José Saramago, Portugal's Nobel Prize winner
Historical novel set during the reign of King João V in 18th century Portugal
The title refers to the massive Mafra Convent the king vows to build
João V promises the convent if the queen gives him an heir
The novel follows the construction of the monument using forced labor
Baltasar Sete-Sóis is a soldier who lost his left hand in war
Blimunda Sete-Luas is a woman with supernatural powers to see inside things
Padre Bartolomeu Lourenço designs a flying machine called the Passarola
Baltasar and Blimunda help the priest build his impossible flying contraption
The novel contrasts royal extravagance with the suffering of common people
Thousands of workers die during the construction of the convent
The Passarola represents human aspiration and imagination versus royal oppression
Blimunda collects human wills (souls) to power the flying machine
Baltasar eventually disappears, arrested by the Inquisition
Blimunda searches for him for years, finally finding him being burned at the stake
The novel critiques religious fanaticism, monarchy, and historical exploitation
Saramago's style features long sentences and minimal punctuation
The work blends historical fact with magical realist elements
The Mafra Convent still stands as one of Portugal's largest monuments
The novel established Saramago as a major international literary figure

profiles.name: Mensagem
clues: Published in 1934 by Fernando Pessoa, Portugal's greatest modernist poet
A collection of 44 poems divided into three parts: Brasão, Mar Português, and O Encoberto
The work presents a mystical vision of Portuguese history and destiny
Each poem focuses on historical figures or events from Portuguese history
The first section, Brasão (Coat of Arms), deals with the founding of Portugal
The second section, Mar Português (Portuguese Sea), covers the Age of Discoveries
The famous line "Valeu a pena? Tudo vale a pena / Se a alma não é pequena" questions if the sacrifices were worthwhile
The third section, O Encoberto (The Hidden One), explores Portuguese messianic mythology
References the Sebastianist myth of King Sebastian's return
The work transforms Portuguese history into symbolic and spiritual narrative
Pessoa presents Portugal's destiny as mystical rather than merely political
The collection won the Antero de Quental Prize in 1934
Written in a more traditional style than Pessoa's heteronym poetry
The poems follow classical Portuguese verse forms
Explores the theme of saudade (untranslatable Portuguese longing/nostalgia)
The work presents Portuguese imperialism in mystical, prophetic terms
Shorter than classical epics but serves as a modernist Portuguese national epic
The collection reflects Pessoa's interest in occultism and esotericism
Each poem is brief, condensed, and symbolically dense
Remains central to Portuguese cultural and literary identity

profiles.name: A Cidade e as Serras
clues: Published posthumously in 1901 by Eça de Queirós
The protagonist Jacinto is a wealthy Portuguese aristocrat living in Paris
Jacinto believes civilization and technology bring happiness
He fills his Paris mansion with every modern invention and luxury
The novel satirizes late 19th century faith in technological progress
Narrated by Jacinto's friend Zé Fernandes, a Portuguese country gentleman
Despite his wealth and gadgets, Jacinto becomes depressed and disillusioned
A legal matter forces Jacinto to visit his neglected estate in rural Portugal
The estate is called Tormes, located in the Serra de Arga mountains
Jacinto gradually discovers happiness in the simple rural life
He abandons Paris to live permanently in the Portuguese countryside
The novel contrasts the artificiality of city life with authentic rural existence
Jacinto marries a local woman and finds fulfillment in agricultural life
The work reflects Eça's mature, mellower view after his earlier satirical novels
Represents a nostalgic idealization of rural Portugal
The novel critiques modernity while celebrating traditional Portuguese values
Features gentle humor rather than Eça's earlier harsh satire
Jacinto's transformation from cosmopolitan sophisticate to contented farmer
The work influenced the Portuguese literary theme of rural versus urban life
Adapted for Portuguese television and remains popular in Portugal

profiles.name: Peregrinação
clues: Travel narrative written by Fernão Mendes Pinto, published posthumously in 1614
Chronicles the author's 21 years of wandering through Asia
Describes travels through India, Southeast Asia, China, and Japan
The author claims to have been captured and enslaved thirteen times
Features incredible adventures including shipwrecks, battles, and escapes
Mendes Pinto was among the first Europeans to reach Japan
The narrative includes detailed observations of Asian cultures and customs
Written in Portuguese during the Age of Discoveries
The author's veracity has been questioned, leading to the pun "Fernão, Mentes? Minto!" (Fernão, do you lie? I lie!)
Despite doubts, many of his accounts have been verified by historians
Describes encounters with pirates, merchants, kings, and common people
Features vivid descriptions of places and peoples unknown to Europeans
The work influenced European knowledge of Asia
Written in episodic form with numerous adventures and misadventures
Mendes Pinto served as a Portuguese soldier, trader, and diplomat
The narrative reflects the brutal realities of Portuguese colonialism
Contains one of the earliest European accounts of Japanese society
The work was translated into multiple languages and widely read
Influenced later travel literature and adventure narratives
Remains an important historical source for 16th century Asian history

profiles.name: Livro do Desassossego
clues: Written by Fernando Pessoa under the semi-heteronym Bernardo Soares
A collection of fragmentary prose pieces never organized by the author
Published posthumously from manuscripts found in Pessoa's trunk
Bernardo Soares is described as an assistant bookkeeper in Lisbon
The work consists of philosophical reflections, dreams, and observations
Written over decades but never intended as a unified book
Explores themes of alienation, tedium, and metaphysical anxiety
The narrator leads a mundane life while experiencing intense inner existence
Features Pessoa's characteristic style of self-analysis and paradox
The Rua dos Douradores (Street of the Gilders) is the setting for Soares's office
Reflects on the gap between external mediocrity and internal richness
The text questions identity, reality, and the nature of existence
Written in a highly literary, dense Portuguese style
Each fragment can be read independently
The work presents Lisbon as both real city and metaphysical landscape
Soares represents the modern condition of alienation and self-consciousness
Different editions organize the fragments differently
The book has become Pessoa's most widely read prose work
Influenced existentialist and postmodern literature
Considered one of the masterpieces of 20th century Portuguese literature

profiles.name: Os Maias
clues: Published in 1888, it's considered Eça de Queirós's masterpiece and greatest achievement in Portuguese literature
The novel spans three generations of the aristocratic Maia family in 19th century Lisbon
The central tragedy involves an incestuous relationship between Carlos da Maia and Maria Eduarda
Carlos and Maria fall deeply in love, unaware that they are brother and sister
Their father, Pedro da Maia, had married a passionate woman who betrayed him and disappeared with their daughter
The novel opens with Afonso da Maia, the patriarch, establishing the family home in Ramalhete
Carlos da Maia is a doctor who abandons his medical career for a life of leisure
The Grémio Literário and horse races at the Hipódromo represent high society entertainment
João da Ega is Carlos's cynical, witty friend who embodies Portuguese intellectual life
The revelation of Carlos and Maria's true relationship comes through a dramatic encounter with their mother
Maria Monforte, the mother, is portrayed as a femme fatale who destroyed the family
The novel critiques Portuguese society's decadence, backwardness, and inability to modernize
Features a famous dinner at the Hotel Central where intellectuals debate Portugal's decline
Alencar represents reactionary Portuguese nationalism and romanticism
The suicide of Pedro da Maia in Santa Olávia haunts the family history
Carlos eventually learns the truth about his relationship with Maria from Guimarães
The novel ends with Carlos and Ega wandering through Lisbon, reflecting on wasted lives
Considered the definitive portrait of Portuguese aristocratic decline in the 19th century
The work combines realism, naturalism, and social criticism
Adapted multiple times for Portuguese television and remains widely read

profiles.name: Frei Luís de Sousa
clues: A romantic drama in three acts written by Almeida Garrett, published in 1844
Based on the historical figure of Manuel de Sousa Coutinho who became a Dominican friar
Set in Portugal during the period of Spanish rule in the early 17th century
The central conflict revolves around the possible return of a husband believed dead
Manuel de Sousa Coutinho married Madalena after her first husband, João de Portugal, disappeared at the Battle of Alcácer Quibir
Their daughter Maria suffers from a mysterious illness linked to the family's secret
The family lives in the palace of Manuel de Sousa in Almada
The palace burns down in the first act, which Manuel sees as a divine sign
A mysterious pilgrim arrives claiming to be João de Portugal, Madalena's first husband
The play explores themes of honor, duty, guilt, and religious devotion
Manuel decides to become a friar if the pilgrim truly is João de Portugal
Madalena faces the anguish of being married to two men, though only one marriage is valid
Maria dies when she learns the truth about her parents' situation
The revelation scene where the pilgrim reveals his identity is one of the most dramatic in Portuguese theater
The protagonist takes religious vows and enters a monastic order
The work is considered the greatest Portuguese romantic drama
Written in prose rather than verse, which was innovative for Portuguese theater
Reflects Portuguese preoccupation with national identity during the Romantic period
The play deals with the lost king Sebastian and the disaster of Alcácer Quibir
Remains a staple of Portuguese education and theater

profiles.name: Amor de Perdição
clues: Written by Camilo Castelo Branco in 1862, one of Portugal's most popular romantic novels
Subtitled "Memórias de uma Família" (Memoirs of a Family)
The novel tells the tragic love story between Simão Botelho and Teresa de Albuquerque
Set in the late 18th and early 19th centuries in northern Portugal
The Botelho and Albuquerque families are feuding neighbors in Viseu
Simão and Teresa fall in love despite their families' violent hatred
Simão is a rebellious student who gets expelled from Coimbra University
Teresa's father, Tadeu de Albuquerque, forbids their relationship and promises her to his cousin Baltasar
Simão kills Baltasar Coutinho in a confrontation to defend Teresa's honor
Simão is arrested, tried, and sentenced to exile in India
Teresa is forced into a convent by her father
Mariana, the blacksmith's daughter, falls hopelessly in love with Simão and helps him
The novel is written as if compiled from family documents and testimonies
Teresa dies in the convent before Simão's ship departs
Simão dies of grief aboard the ship to India after learning of Teresa's death
Mariana throws herself into the sea after Simão's death, dying with his body in her arms
The novel exemplifies the ultra-romantic style with its extreme emotions and tragic fate
Camilo wrote the novel while imprisoned in Porto for his own scandalous love affair
The work critiques paternal tyranny and social conventions
Remains one of the most read novels in Portuguese literature

profiles.name: A Relíquia
clues: Published in 1887 by Eça de Queirós as a satire of religious hypocrisy
The protagonist, Teodorico Raposo (Raposão), is a young libertine who pretends to be devout
Teodorico hopes to inherit the fortune of his wealthy, pious aunt Titi (D. Patrocínio)
The novel alternates between Lisbon and Jerusalem, where Teodorico makes a pilgrimage
Teodorico travels to the Holy Land to bring back a sacred relic for his aunt
In Jerusalem, he has a hallucinatory vision of Christ's Passion
The vision presents a naturalistic, humanized version of biblical events
Teodorico meets Mary Magdalene in his vision, portrayed as a sensual woman
He also encounters Pontius Pilate, the Pharisees, and witnesses the crucifixion
Upon returning to Lisbon, Teodorico mistakenly presents his aunt with a prostitute's nightgown instead of the relic
The mix-up occurs because he packed both the sacred relic and a souvenir from a prostitute
His aunt discovers his hypocrisy and disinherits him, leaving her fortune to the Church
The novel satirizes religious fanaticism and false devotion
Teodorico represents the Portuguese bourgeois who uses religion for social advancement
The Jerusalem vision chapters are among Eça's most powerful writing
The work was controversial for its irreverent treatment of sacred subjects
Eça criticizes the commercialization of religion and fake pilgrimages
The novel explores the gap between religious appearance and moral reality
Features Eça's characteristic irony and social criticism
Considered one of Eça's most audacious and experimental novels

profiles.name: Viagens na Minha Terra
clues: Published in 1846 by Almeida Garrett, a foundational text of Portuguese Romanticism
Combines travelogue, political commentary, love story, and literary criticism
The narrator travels from Lisbon to Santarém, describing the Portuguese landscape and people
The journey becomes an excuse for digressions on Portuguese politics, history, and culture
Embedded within is the tragic love story of Carlos and Joaninha
Carlos is a liberal who fought in the Portuguese Civil War
Joaninha is raised by her grandmother, the blind Francisca, in the Valley of Santarém
Carlos falls in love with Joaninha but is torn between her and his political ambitions
The novel criticizes both absolutists and liberals, showing disillusionment with politics
Features the famous motto "Eu por mim, quero voltar à minha pobre casa" (I want to return to my poor house)
The narrator constantly interrupts the story to address the reader directly
Reflects on the state of Portuguese literature and the need for a national literature
The Vale de Santarém is presented as an idealized Portuguese paradise
The work mixes prose and poetry, realism and romanticism
Carlos's abandonment of Joaninha symbolizes Portugal's betrayal of its own values
The novel pioneered the romantic travel narrative in Portuguese literature
Garrett criticizes Portuguese backwardness while celebrating Portuguese landscape and traditions
The fragmented, digressive structure influenced later Portuguese fiction
Considered essential reading for understanding Portuguese Romanticism
The work reflects Garrett's own political involvement and disillusionment

profiles.name: Contos
clues: Collection of short stories by Eça de Queirós, showcasing his mastery of the form
Includes some of Eça's most famous stories written throughout his career
"O Suave Milagre" (The Gentle Miracle) is a tender story about faith and kindness
"Civilização" (Civilization) satirizes European colonial attitudes
"A Aia" (The Governess) explores class differences and thwarted ambitions
"José Matias" tells the story of a man's lifelong devotion to an impossible love
"O Tesouro" (The Treasure) is a parable about greed and misfortune
The stories range from realist social criticism to lyrical, symbolic tales
Many were published in Brazilian and Portuguese journals before being collected
"Singularidades de uma Rapariga Loura" (Peculiarities of a Blonde Girl) depicts a disillusioning love affair
The stories often focus on the Portuguese bourgeoisie and their moral failings
Eça's ironic narrative voice is present throughout the collection
Some stories have oriental or exotic settings, reflecting Eça's time as a diplomat
"No Moinho" (At the Mill) is a dark tale of poverty and desperation
The stories demonstrate Eça's range from satire to pathos
Many explore themes of illusion versus reality
The collection shows Eça's evolution from strict realism to more symbolic writing
His short fiction influenced Portuguese modernist writers
The stories remain popular and are frequently anthologized
Demonstrates Eça's status as Portugal's greatest prose stylist

profiles.name: O Primo Basílio
clues: Published in 1878 by Eça de Queirós, his second major novel after O Crime do Padre Amaro
The novel tells the story of Luísa, a bourgeois Lisbon woman who commits adultery
Luísa's husband Jorge is an honest, hardworking engineer
Basílio, Luísa's cousin and former suitor, returns from Brazil as a wealthy dandy
Basílio seduces Luísa in a series of meetings at a rented room called "o Paraíso" (Paradise)
The affair is discovered by Juliana, the couple's spiteful, hunchbacked maid
Juliana blackmails Luísa with the love letters she wrote to Basílio
The novel depicts Luísa's psychological torment as Juliana's demands escalate
Basílio abandons Luísa and returns to Paris, leaving her to face the consequences alone
Luísa's friend Leopoldina represents moral corruption and cynical hedonism
Conselheiro Acácio is a pompous neighbor who speaks in clichés, becoming a symbol of Portuguese mediocrity
Jorge's friend Sebastião tries to help Luísa recover the letters
Juliana dies from illness before she can expose Luísa
Luísa confesses everything to Jorge and dies from nervous fever
The novel critiques the superficial education of Portuguese women
Eça shows how romantic novels corrupt Luísa's sense of reality
The work was controversial and accused of being immoral and pornographic
It's considered a masterpiece of Portuguese Realism
The novel depicts bourgeois Lisbon life in meticulous detail
Remains one of the most read and studied Portuguese novels

profiles.name: Sermão de Santo António aos Peixes
clues: A famous sermon preached by Padre António Vieira in São Luís do Maranhão, Brazil in 1654
Ostensibly addressed to fish, but actually criticizing Portuguese colonists
Uses the biblical story of St. Anthony preaching to fish when people wouldn't listen
The sermon is divided into sections praising virtues of fish and condemning their vices
Vieira praises small fish for their humility and numbers
The sermon criticizes predatory large fish as symbols of oppressive colonizers
The "roncadores" (grunting fish) represent those who complain but do nothing
The "pegadores" (remoras) symbolize parasites who attach themselves to the powerful
Flying fish represent those who rise above their station and fall
Vieira uses the allegorical sermon to criticize slavery and exploitation of indigenous peoples
The work is a masterpiece of Baroque rhetoric and persuasive oratory
Vieira's elaborate metaphors and biblical references create layers of meaning
The sermon demonstrates Vieira's courage in confronting powerful interests
Written in elaborate, ornate Portuguese characteristic of the Baroque period
Vieira was a Jesuit missionary who defended indigenous rights
The sermon exemplifies the conceptismo style of Baroque literature
It's one of the most famous works of Portuguese Baroque prose
The text is studied for its rhetorical brilliance and social criticism
Vieira's sermons influenced Portuguese prose style for generations
Remains a classic of Portuguese and Brazilian literature

profiles.name: História do Cerco de Lisboa
clues: Published in 1989 by José Saramago, blending history and fiction
The protagonist, Raimundo Silva, is a proofreader for a publishing house
Silva is assigned to proofread a history book about the 1147 Siege of Lisbon
He deliberately inserts the word "not" into the text, changing historical fact
The alteration claims the Crusaders did NOT help Portuguese forces capture Lisbon from the Moors
This act of creative rebellion leads Silva to imagine an alternative history
The novel alternates between Silva's contemporary story and his imagined medieval narrative
Silva falls in love with Maria Sara, his editor at the publishing house
In the imagined story, a Portuguese soldier named Mogueime loves a Moorish woman
The medieval narrative explores the actual Siege of Lisbon with fictional characters
Saramago questions the nature of historical truth and the role of fiction
The novel explores how small changes can alter the course of history
Features Saramago's characteristic long sentences and minimal punctuation
The work reflects on the relationship between historians and their subjects
Silva's "correction" of history represents individual agency against official narratives
The novel depicts contemporary Lisbon alongside medieval Lisbon
Saramago uses the siege as a metaphor for Portuguese identity formation
The love story between Silva and Maria Sara mirrors the medieval romance
The work questions the authority of historical texts
Considered one of Saramago's most accessible and engaging novels

profiles.name: A Ilustre Casa de Ramires
clues: Published posthumously in 1900, Eça de Queirós's last completed novel
The protagonist, Gonçalo Mendes Ramires, is an impoverished nobleman in rural Portugal
Gonçalo lives in the ancestral Tower of Santa Ireneia in the fictional town of Vila Clara
He is writing a historical novel about his heroic medieval ancestor, Tructesindo Ramires
The novel contrasts Gonçalo's glorious literary creation with his own cowardly reality
Gonçalo is humiliated by the Lousadas, a wealthy family of merchants
He fails to avenge insults to his sister and himself, showing moral weakness
The parallel medieval narrative depicts the brave deeds of Tructesindo
Gradually, Gonçalo begins to live up to his ancestral ideals
He finally confronts his enemies and defends his family honor
The novel explores Portuguese national character and identity
Eça questions whether Portugal's future lies in recovering its past glory
The work is more optimistic than Eça's earlier novels
Gonçalo eventually abandons rural Portugal to seek fortune in Africa
The ending suggests Portuguese regeneration might come through colonial enterprise
The novel reflects on the relationship between past and present
Features Eça's mature, mellower style with less harsh satire
The contrast between the two narratives creates ironic commentary
The work examines Portuguese nobility's decline and possible redemption
Considered Eça's most complex meditation on Portuguese identity

profiles.name: Don Quixote
clues: Published in two parts in 1605 and 1615 by Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra
Considered the first modern novel and one of the greatest works of fiction ever written
The protagonist is Alonso Quixano, an aging hidalgo who loses his sanity from reading chivalric romances
He renames himself and sets out to revive chivalry and serve his nation as a knight-errant
Accompanied by his faithful squire Sancho Panza, a simple farmer who serves as his comic counterpart
The famous windmill scene where the knight mistakes windmills for giants occurs early in the narrative
The protagonist's horse is named Rocinante, an old, worn-out nag
He imagines a peasant woman, Aldonza Lorenzo, as his idealized lady Dulcinea del Toboso
Part Two references the publication of Part One, creating metafictional layers
Features the character Sansón Carrasco who disguises himself to defeat the knight and cure his madness
The knight becomes the Knight of the White Moon in the second part
In Barcelona, the protagonist is defeated by Carrasco disguised as the Knight of the White Moon
The novel satirizes the chivalric romance genre popular in Cervantes's time
On his deathbed, Alonso Quixano regains his sanity and renounces chivalric romances
The work influenced countless later novels and gave birth to the term "quixotic"
Contains the famous phrase "tilting at windmills" meaning fighting imaginary enemies
Sancho Panza serves as governor of the island of Barataria in Part Two
The novel explores the nature of reality versus illusion and idealism versus realism
Translated into over 140 languages and has never been out of print
Influenced writers from Fielding and Sterne to Nabokov and Borges

profiles.name: The Divine Comedy
clues: An epic poem written by Dante Alighieri between 1308 and 1320
Divided into three parts: Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso
Written in terza rima, a rhyme scheme Dante invented consisting of interlocking three-line stanzas
The narrator journeys through Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven during Easter week 1300
The Roman poet Virgil serves as guide through Hell and Purgatory
Beatrice, Dante's idealized love, guides him through Paradise
Contains 14,233 lines divided into 100 cantos
Each of the three sections contains 33 cantos, plus one introductory canto in Inferno
Hell is structured as nine circles descending toward the center of the Earth
Famous punishments include Paolo and Francesca trapped in the winds of the second circle
Count Ugolino eternally gnaws on Archbishop Ruggieri's skull in the ninth circle
At Hell's center, Satan is frozen in ice, eternally chewing Judas, Brutus, and Cassius
The inscription above Hell's gate reads "Abandon all hope, ye who enter here"
Purgatory is depicted as a mountain with seven terraces corresponding to the seven deadly sins
Written in Italian rather than Latin, establishing Tuscan dialect as the literary standard
The poem serves as an allegory of the soul's journey toward God
Features historical and contemporary figures Dante places in various levels according to their sins or virtues
Influenced by both Christian theology and classical literature
Considered the greatest work of Italian literature
The word "comedy" in the title refers to the happy ending, not humor

profiles.name: Ulysses
clues: Published in 1922 by Irish writer James Joyce
The novel follows Leopold Bloom through Dublin on June 16, 1904, now celebrated as Bloomsday
Parallels Homer's Odyssey with 18 episodes corresponding to episodes in the Greek epic
The protagonist is a Jewish advertising salesman who represents the modern hero
Stephen Dedalus, protagonist of Joyce's earlier novel, appears as the Telemachus figure
Molly Bloom's final unpunctuated interior monologue is one of literature's most famous passages
Each episode is written in a different literary style
The "Wandering Rocks" episode uses montage technique to show simultaneous events across Dublin
The "Oxen of the Sun" episode traces the evolution of English prose style
The "Circe" episode is written as an expressionistic play
The novel was banned in the United States and United Kingdom for obscenity until the 1930s
Contains the famous final word "Yes" repeated in Molly Bloom's soliloquy
Stephen Dedalus mourns his recently deceased mother throughout the novel
Bloom's day includes attending a funeral, eating lunch, visiting newspaper offices, and encountering anti-Semitism
The novel takes place entirely within Dublin, with exact addresses and locations
Features stream-of-consciousness technique that influenced countless later writers
The "Sirens" episode is structured like a fugue with musical techniques
Bloom's wife Molly is having an affair with Blazes Boylan
Contains extensive wordplay, puns, and allusions to Irish history and culture
Considered one of the most important novels of the 20th century

profiles.name: Mrs Dalloway
clues: Published in 1925 by Virginia Woolf
The novel takes place during a single day in June 1923 in London
Clarissa Dalloway is preparing to host an evening party
The narrative uses stream-of-consciousness technique to move between characters' minds
Septimus Warren Smith, a World War I veteran suffering from shell shock, provides a parallel narrative
The novel explores the aftermath of World War I on British society
Clarissa reflects on her past and her choice to marry Richard Dalloway rather than Peter Walsh
Peter Walsh returns from India and visits Clarissa unexpectedly
Sally Seton, Clarissa's youthful friend and possible romantic interest, reappears
Septimus hallucinates and sees his dead friend Evans throughout the day
Dr. William Bradshaw and Sir William represent oppressive medical authority
Septimus throws himself from a window to escape forced institutionalization
Clarissa learns of Septimus's death at her party and reflects on his sacrifice
The novel uses the striking of Big Ben to mark time throughout the day
Originally titled "The Hours," which became the title of Michael Cunningham's novel about it
The narrative technique allows the reader into multiple characters' thoughts and memories
Clarissa had kissed Sally Seton in her youth, a moment she remembers as pure ecstasy
The novel critiques British class society and the treatment of mental illness
Woolf experiments with representing the flow of time and consciousness
Considered one of the masterpieces of modernist fiction

profiles.name: The Trial
clues: Published posthumously in 1925, Franz Kafka died before completing the novel
The protagonist Josef K. is arrested on his thirtieth birthday without being told his crime
He is never informed of the charges against him throughout the entire novel
The novel depicts an absurd, nightmarish legal system and bureaucracy
Josef K. continues his job at a bank while navigating the mysterious court system
His encounters with the court take place in unexpected locations like attics and tenements
The washerwoman in the court building offers to help but only complicates matters
The painter Titorelli offers to help but can only achieve apparent acquittal or indefinite postponement
The novel includes the parable "Before the Law" about a man waiting his entire life at a gate
A priest tells Josef K. the parable in a cathedral chapter
Josef K.'s uncle brings him to see the lawyer Huld, who is largely ineffective
Leni, the lawyer's maid, becomes involved with Josef K.
The block manufacturer appears as another client, abasing himself before the lawyer
Josef K. eventually dismisses the lawyer due to lack of progress
The court operates in hidden locations throughout the city, parallel to normal society
On the eve of his thirty-first birthday, two men come to execute Josef K.
He is taken to a quarry and killed "like a dog"
The novel explores themes of guilt, alienation, and powerlessness
Kafka's friend Max Brod published the novel against Kafka's wishes
The term "Kafkaesque" derives from this and Kafka's other works depicting absurd bureaucratic nightmares

profiles.name: Madame Bovary
clues: Published in 1856 by Gustave Flaubert after five years of meticulous work
The novel was initially serialized in La Revue de Paris
Flaubert and the publisher were tried for offending public morality but acquitted
The protagonist Emma Bovary is the wife of a country doctor in provincial France
Emma was educated in a convent and develops unrealistic romantic ideals from novels
She marries Charles Bovary, a mediocre but kind country doctor
Disappointed by the dullness of married life, Emma seeks excitement and romance
She has affairs with Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy landowner, and Léon Dupuis, a law clerk
Emma accumulates massive debts buying luxury goods from the merchant Lheureux
When her debts are called in, she desperately seeks money from her lovers, who refuse
Unable to pay and facing exposure, Emma commits suicide by consuming arsenic
Charles discovers Emma's infidelities after her death but forgives her
Charles dies of grief, and their daughter Berthe is sent to work in a cotton mill
The pharmacist Homais represents pseudo-scientific pretension and receives the Legion of Honor
Flaubert famously said "the protagonist's character" identifying with his character
The novel exemplifies literary Realism with its precise, objective descriptions
Flaubert spent days perfecting single paragraphs, seeking le mot juste (the right word)
The novel critiques romantic idealism and the bourgeoisie
Emma Bovary became the archetype of the dissatisfied, adulterous wife
Influenced countless later novels about provincial life and female protagonists

profiles.name: War and Peace
clues: Published serially between 1865 and 1869 by Leo Tolstoy
One of the longest novels ever written, with 361 chapters
Follows five aristocratic families during the Napoleonic Wars
The novel focuses on Pierre Bezukhov, Prince Andrei Bolkonsky, and Natasha Rostova
Pierre is the illegitimate son who unexpectedly inherits a vast fortune
Andrei is a disillusioned aristocrat seeking meaning through military glory
Natasha is a young woman whose romantic and spiritual journey is central to the plot
The novel depicts actual historical events including the Battle of Austerlitz
Napoleon's invasion of Russia in 1812 forms the backdrop of the later sections
Features the burning of Moscow and Pierre's captivity by the French
Tolstoy includes essays on history and philosophy throughout the narrative
Prince Andrei is mortally wounded at the Battle of Borodino
Andrei and Natasha reconcile before his death
Pierre undergoes spiritual transformation through his experiences as a prisoner
The peasant soldier Platon Karataev influences Pierre's philosophical outlook
Pierre eventually marries Natasha after years of searching for meaning
The epilogue is set in 1820 and shows the characters' later lives
Tolstoy argues that history is driven by countless small actions, not great men
The novel contrasts the artificiality of aristocratic life with the authenticity of peasant wisdom
Considered one of the greatest novels ever written

profiles.name: In Search of Lost Time
clues: Written by Marcel Proust and published in seven volumes between 1913 and 1927
Originally titled À la recherche du temps perdu in French
One of the longest novels ever written, approximately 1.5 million words
The narrator's life from childhood to middle age unfolds through involuntary memories
The famous opening involves the narrator's memories triggered by a madeleine dipped in tea
The novel explores memory, time, art, and society in Belle Époque France
Charles Swann is a wealthy Jewish art lover whose love affair is detailed in the first volume
Odette de Crécy is a courtesan who becomes Swann's obsession and later his wife
The Baron de Charlus is a complex character whose homosexuality is gradually revealed
The Guermantes family represents the highest levels of French aristocracy
Albertine is the narrator's lover whose captivity and escape form major plot points
The seaside town of Balbec is based on Cabourg where Proust vacationed
The narrator discovers that time lost can be recaptured through art
The final volume reveals the narrator's decision to write the novel we have just read
Proust wrote much of the novel while bedridden with asthma in a cork-lined room
The novel employs incredibly long sentences and elaborate metaphors
Explores themes of jealousy, homosexuality, social climbing, and artistic creation
The work influenced modernist and postmodernist writers profoundly
Considered one of the supreme achievements of 20th century literature
The madeleine scene has become iconic in discussions of memory and literature

profiles.name: The Sound and the Fury
clues: Published in 1929 by William Faulkner
The novel is divided into four sections, each with a different narrator and time period
The first section is narrated by Benjy Compson, who has an intellectual disability
Benjy's section is told in stream-of-consciousness without conventional linear time
The second section is narrated by Quentin Compson on the day of his suicide at Harvard
Quentin is obsessed with his sister Caddy's loss of virginity and subsequent pregnancy
The third section is narrated by Jason Compson, the bitter, cruel youngest brother
Jason embezzles money sent for Caddy's daughter, also named Quentin
The final section is told by a third-person narrator following Dilsey, the family's servant
Dilsey represents stability and moral strength in contrast to the declining Compson family
The novel depicts the decline of a once-aristocratic Southern family
Set in Jefferson, Mississippi, Faulkner's fictional Yoknapatawpha County
Caddy Compson never narrates but is the central figure in her brothers' obsessions
The young Quentin steals the money Jason has hidden and runs away with a carnival worker
Jason pursues her but fails to catch her, losing all the embezzled money
The novel explores themes of time, memory, family decline, and Southern decay
Faulkner uses different typefaces and italic passages to indicate shifts in time
The title comes from Macbeth's soliloquy about life being "a tale told by an idiot"
Faulkner considered it his greatest artistic achievement
The novel exemplifies literary modernism with its fractured narrative and experimental techniques

profiles.name: Invisible Man
clues: Published in 1952 by Ralph Ellison
The unnamed narrator begins by declaring "begins with a stunning revelation about his condition"
The novel opens with the narrator living underground, stealing electricity
The protagonist recounts his journey from the South to Harlem
As a young man, he participates in a brutal "battle royal" for white entertainment
He wins a scholarship to an all-black college modeled on Tuskegee Institute
Dr. Bledsoe, the college president, expels him for showing a white trustee the harsh realities of Black life
The narrator moves to New York with letters of recommendation that secretly sabotage him
He works briefly at a paint factory that makes "Optic White" paint
An explosion at the factory lands him in the hospital where doctors experiment on him
He joins the Brotherhood, a political organization resembling the Communist Party
Brother Jack is the one-eyed leader of the Brotherhood
Tod Clifton, a Brotherhood member, is killed by police after leaving the organization
Ras the Exhorter (later Ras the Destroyer) represents Black nationalism
The narrator is betrayed by the Brotherhood during race riots in Harlem
He falls into a manhole and decides to live underground
The novel explores Black identity, invisibility, and the search for self in racist America
Uses symbolism, surrealism, and jazz-like structure
Won the National Book Award and is considered one of the greatest American novels
The invisibility metaphor represents how society refuses to see Black individuals as fully human
